importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when Marc Benioff publicly backtracked on his comments about the National Guard deployment in San Francisco, indicating a shift in stance following public backlash.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Benioff made initial controversial comments supporting Trump's National Guard deployment, leading to public criticism and the subsequent apology on the same day.

keyTakeAways: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, initially suggested that President Donald Trump should deploy the National Guard to San Francisco to address safety concerns, sparking widespread criticism.

Benioff later apologized, stating that after consulting with local officials and residents, he no longer believes the National Guard is needed, and that his earlier comment was made out of 'abundance of caution'.
The annual Dreamforce conference in San Francisco, which drew tens of thousands of attendees, provided the context for Benioff's remarks, as security concerns were heightened during the event.
Benioff's comments were part of a broader trend of Bay Area tech billionaires aligning with President Trump’s policies, including support for federal troop deployment in Democratic-led cities.
The controversy led to internal fallout, with prominent venture capitalist Ron Conway resigning from the Salesforce Foundation board.

Internal documents suggest Salesforce has previously supported Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), including pitching AI tools to enhance ICE investigations and deportation efforts, raising concerns about corporate ties to immigration enforcement.
Salesforce has not responded to media inquiries about these internal documents, though it has acknowledged past government contracts under previous administrations (Obama and Biden).

summaryOfNewsArticle: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, initially suggested that President Donald Trump deploy the National Guard to San Francisco to address safety concerns during the company’s Dreamforce conference, sparking backlash from critics including venture capitalist Ron Conway, who resigned from the Salesforce Foundation board. Benioff later apologized, stating that after consulting local officials and residents, he no longer believes the National Guard is needed and that his earlier comment was made out of caution. The incident also revealed internal Salesforce documents suggesting the company supported ICE operations, including AI-driven tools for immigration enforcement, raising concerns about corporate alignment with federal immigration policy. This reflects a broader trend among Bay Area tech leaders aligning with Trump’s policies.
title: Marc Benioff apologizes for suggesting National Guard be sent to San Francisco
